segments.text: That tape didn't run its full 30 minutes, which is all right.
You're sure you're getting a recording, aren't you?
Because it's not so irritating as to record and get nothing.
That's right.
I'm sure I am.
We can check that out.
All right, as long as you're sure.
Well, anyway, as I say, my wife suggested to him that he ought to do something about the fireplace and get it enlarged.
And a week or two later, he came round and said, my wife asked him whether he'd done anything.
He said, yes, I've done something.
She, from the wording of it, she was a little suspicious.
She said, what have you done, Harold?
Well, he said,
there are two ways of keeping warm in a room.
One is to have a larger fireplace, and the other is to get closer to it.

And he said, what I've done is I've had the curb around the fireplace put closer to the fireplace, so that I always sit on the floor, and I can now get closer to it, and the heat goes off as the inverse square, so I shall keep warm.
But anyway, he took
to coming round almost every evening to the apartment we had in Cambridge.
He'd stand out in the street and shout until we let him in.
So we had this, what I regarded as an old gentleman.
He was only in his 40s, but I was in my early 20s.
And he used to come round and talk about geophysics and so on.
I learnt a lot from him.
Well, then my main thing was I decided to widen the ranges
Essentially, the thing was called the Department of Geodesy and Geophysics, but it was really only concerned with lecturing to undergraduates on surveying and measuring gravity.
And I started off to add seismology.
And we also added a little terrestrial magnetism.
I made gravity measurements when I was in East Africa.
and the seismology was a big project.
And then I met this character, Dick Field, who said, I must go to sea and do some seismology at sea.
And he arranged for me in 1937 to go out to sea with Maurice Huey.
This is the first time I'd been to America.
I came to America in the summer of 1937, and I went out to sea with the Coastal Geodetic Survey.
I went...

around the east coast with field we were driving down i remember to see the geophysical lab in washington and i said you know i'm sorry always sorry that as a student i never did any geology oh it's absurd you must learn some geology come on we'll go and learn some geology um and we rushed off instead of going to the geophysical lab in washington we rushed off in the other direction
And he took me over the Appalachian section in which he'd done his PhD between Harrisburg and the Belfonte up to State College.
This wonderful, beautiful section through a slightly folded mountain range.
And he showed me what geology was about.
He really did teach me enough geology to know what it was about and to make me believe I can make up the rest.
Anyway, then he sent me out to sea with Ewing, and Ewing, by this time, he'd been doing some work on the continental shelf, and this was his first foray beyond the edge of the continental shelf.
And I've given an account of this in the thing I wrote about Ewing.
And we had a most interesting time in this little vessel.
She was a sailing vessel, an auxiliary engine, the Atlantis from Woods Hole.
And this was my first trip in an oceanographic vessel.
My trouble as an oceanographer has always been that I'm seasick.
And these little vessels didn't really suit me.
But we had an extremely instructive time.
I've given an account in that paper of how we decided we needed cast TNT
instead of flake TNT, and we made it on board the ship by heating up TNT in an electric coffee pot and pouring it into paper bowls, and all kinds of improvisations of the sort.
And Ewing was a man after my own heart, but as I say, I've written about him, and I owe a great deal to him.
And then I went home, and the next year I went out to sea with a man called Tom Gaskell, and Ben Brown had been doing the gravity in submarines.
We'd already, before we met Field, decided to do gravity measurements for submarines.
And we did our first seismic work on the continental shelf and found these great thicknesses of sediments, which had also been found by Ewing over on the east coast of the United States.
And this was the great discovery of the enormous sedimentary thicknesses, 10, 20, 30, 40,000 feet, some places 10 kilometers of sediment, which, of course, are the home
of the offshore oil.
And it's interesting that the oil companies at the time were not the least interested.
Ewing tried to get money off an oil company to look for the thickness of the sediments off the east coast of the United States.
And they weren't interested at all.
The chairman of Standard Oil simply said, there's plenty of oil in the Middle East.
We can buy the oil we want.
There's a good deal of oil in Texas.
We're all right.
And they had no idea what was going to happen.
And it shows the difficulty of prediction.
Because these people weren't foolish.
They knew their business.
They were making a lot of money.
But you couldn't see that far ahead that there were going to be these troubles and you'd need to look for oil at sea.
It's an interesting sidelight, I think, on the nature of industry before the war.
I mean, now you'd have no trouble at all.
I don't think you'd have much trouble
I mean, the minerals companies now are looking at minerals at sea.
They don't need very much persuading.
But then it was really very different.
Well, anyway, we worked on this up to the war.
We got a good section of the thickness of the sediments out to the edge of the continental shelf.
And we started to turn our thoughts to all kinds of other things.
I got interested in heat flow, first of all on land.
I had a graduate student working on land.
And I went to South Africa before the war and did measurements of heat flow in the mines.
And I thought of a method of doing this at sea.
I thought of this before the war, but war came too soon.
And so we didn't do it before the war.
Now, how much do you want me to... Let's stop there.
You asked me other questions about the pre-war period.
Right.
I don't want to go into the war until I've come to work with the submarine.
You've already made a comment on how Cambridge compares today with Cambridge 45 years ago.
Would you see Cambridge now as more specialised than it was when you went to school there?
No, I think less so.
In the sense that if we're talking about...
Are you talking about the undergraduate course or the sort of things that graduate students sort of research and so on?
Sort of things graduate students do, really.
Well, no, I think less specialized.
You see, at that time, Rutherford had this single-minded devotion to the nucleus, nuclear physics.
Now, the interest has broadened a great deal.
If one takes a look at the Cavendish today, they're doing a great variety of things.
They're interested in a great deal of solid state work, low temperature work, electron microscopy, all kinds of things.
And I would say that generally, graduate students have a broader knowledge of what science is about.
I mean lots of them now of course go into biophysics.
This is the big thing that's had this tremendous development.
Earth science, the sort of thing I've been engaged in, and molecular biology are the great revolutions of the post-war period and to some extent astronomy.
These are things all on the periphery of physics.
They're not the central core of particle and nuclear physics, as Rutherford saw physics.
They are things that are peripheral.
And these have had this tremendous development.
And this has, I think, affected people's whole attitude to science, that now one looks for the growing points on the periphery of a subject rather than the central core of it.

physicist you're taking a very big gamble because you may turn out to be Einstein but you'll probably spend your time doing rather trivial things in a very competitive field with a very large number of other people and students are bored with this a few I always ask graduate students when they want to come and work with me why they want to come and work with me and why they don't do something else
And in the old days, I'm talking about 20 years ago, they used to say, well, you know, I've come to realize that I'm not good enough for particle physics or for solid state physics.
And Mr. Somebody or other advised me to come and see you.
Nowadays, they say something different.
I say, why don't you go into particle physics?
They say, it's so dull.
I'd like something that's growing and interesting where I can make an impression.
And of course, also, this is hitched on to this vague feeling that students have for what they call relevance.
I don't think they know what they mean by relevance quite.

But they mean something which is connected with what they see as the real world, what they see as human interests, particularly human interests in pollution, the state of the world, energy, all these things.
So I think the attitude of students has changed.
In my day, as a student, it was felt to be a definitely second best choice not to go into the central core of physics, the developing study of the nucleus and of particles.
And this has changed.
Is that...?
Yeah, yeah.
I'm struck by...
by your ability to write, which is rather unusual for American scientists, if I may say so.
Is this a product of your sort of classical education, or did you have a classical education?
Well, let me say, I was an extremely unsuccessful schoolboy.
I was, as a small boy, age of 10 or so, I was extremely disturbed.
I don't quite know why.
In any case, it's not relevant to your inquiry.
I was unhappy at home, unhappy at school, for no real reason.
And I got very behind hand, and my parents took me to some kind of primitive psychiatrist or psychologist, and he said, take him away from his day school, send him away to school, to boarding school.
And I think the man must have had in mind
that he wanted to get me out of what was obviously for me a difficult environment.
And I think it was partly the great anxiety of my parents that I might be a very low-grade person.
My father never believed I could earn my living.
Well, anyway, I went away to school and quite suddenly I felt released and I was put into the bottom form
two or three years below my age.
And in two, three years, I went right up to the top of the school.
No trouble, no trouble at all.
Most extraordinary transformation.
And curiously enough, an identical thing has just happened to my grandson, who refused to learn to write about the age I was in trouble.
And his mother said,
Did he do something?
So I got him into the same school.
What public school did you go to?
I went to Repton.
I went to Repton at the age of 14.
And I disliked it for the first two or three years.
Then I sort of came to terms with it.
And it was a good school in a very old fashioned sense.
They didn't bother much about you.
They left you alone.
You could do what you liked.
I had strong mathematical and physical interests.
I didn't pay much attention to anything else.
And I was more or less in a way self-educated.
And I suddenly realized that I could, in fact, no one would worry much what I did.
And I got, in England at that time, there was a critical exam that you took 16, 17.
I was still a bit behind and I took it at 17.
Well, I disliked him intensely.
I'm just telling the story.
It shows my sort of attitude to authority at that time.
I took a dislike to my foremaster.
And we quarreled a good deal.
And I remember he asked us to write an essay on what historical character we'd most like to have met.
And I thought, I'll tell him what I think of him.
So I sat down and I wrote an essay which started with the reasons for not wishing to meet
any of the historical characters that he admired.
I said the Duke of Wellington and Napoleon were little better than murderers.
A view I don't hold now of the Duke of Wellington.
And went through a list of all the people he'd held up to us as admirable, and said I wouldn't have made any of them if I'd been paid to.
And the man I'd have liked to meet was Faraday.
Well, then the man lost his temper over this, wrote a piece at the bottom,
saying, you beastly little boy, public school education is thrown away on you.
And I had this thing framed and hung up in my study.
And I haven't got it now.
I lost it when I left school.
But anyway, I was pleased with this and thought I was definitely making progress.
And then I came out one from bottom.
I was 22nd out of 23 in this form at the end of the year.
But fortunately, the prize for the year was given on the results of a public examination.
in which I came top.
So when the results were read out for all the school and the parents, the headmaster read out, Bullard, 22, Snooks, 23, four-prize Bullard.
I thought I'd definitely scored off this man.
I mean, an absolute fool, of course.
He got me bottom of the four.
But this is an answer to your question in the sense that I must have been able to write, you see, and make things plausible.
And the man was very nice to me.
He asked me, the form master asked me to go around to tea and I went around there and he said, look, it's clear I've made a mistake and I hope you don't hold it against me.
And we were good friends after this.
But anyway, it was a funny sort of school, sort of ill-organised, do what you like.

I remember when I was, the next year after this, I was not in the top form, one from the top form, and I went in for, it was an engineering prize, and I went in for it, I thought it would be fun to, and
So I went in for the engineering prize and came out top.
I thought it was nice, I got the prize.
Not a bit of it.

The headmaster, who afterwards became Archbishop of Canterbury, ruled that I was ineligible because I was in the fifth form and not in the sixth form, and that the man in the sixth form who'd come second in the exams would get the prize.
Well, I thought this was a joke.
I mean, it seemed to me funny.
I thought the headmaster, who had a rather perverted sense of humour, disregarded this as funny and wanted to see how I'd react.
And so I went round to my house master and I told him this as a joke.
I said, you know what Elsans has done?
And I explained.
And he said, you know why he's done this?
And I said, no, I suppose he thought it was funny.
No, he said, it's not that.
There's a cup for the house that gets most prizes.
And we are neck and neck with his house.
And as a story about an archbishop, I thought it was instructive.
Yes.
I got to know him later on when he was archbishop.
I got to know him a bit.
And we were good friends.
I asked him down a few months before he died to give a talk at Churchill College in Cambridge.
He came and talked to undergraduates.
And he chose to talk on ethics.
And he gave the most wonderful talk.
He was the greatest fun.
He really was a very entertaining man.
He was the best after-dinner speaker in England.
And really, very good fun.
This is Fisher, Dr. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury.
The other memory I have of him is that we used to have a scripture lesson on Sunday mornings.
And there was some miserable little man who used to take us to scripture.
I remember his name, but I won't repeat it.
Anyway, this was a shambles.
We were supposed to be reading a book, the book of Isaiah.
And we all took in things that interested us.
I remember there was a man took in
a journal called Engineering, which is about the same size as the Los Angeles Times.
I used to sit reading this in the front row, and I used to scratch my head about mathematics and so on.
We were all getting on with our own affairs, and Manuel was running it, obviously didn't mind much what we did.
He read some book of his own.
And one day, the headmaster, Fisher, came in and said he proposed to hold an examination.
We'd all put our books away, of course, as soon as the capital would go on.
We were wondering how on earth this chap would run things and get out of this.
And he said to headmaster, you know, the boys are very interested in Isaiah, and we shan't be able to finish the book and have an examination.
I would really like them to finish it and not have the examination.
And the headmaster sort of grinned.
He obviously saw what was going on and went out again.
Well, I'm trying to give the picture of a,
entirely disorganized school, see, that went in this extraordinary way.
And then at the end of my school days, I had to get into Cambridge, and I had to take a Latin examination.
And I hadn't done, I'd stopped doing Latin when I was about 12 or 13.
And so I read all 14, something of that sort, and I really didn't know any Latin at all.
So I decided, in the term before this exam, to devote a substantial amount of time to learning Latin.
Then I got measles.
and I wasn't allowed to read, and I was only left with three weeks to learn Latin.
And I went round to see a man who I knew taught Latin, who I knew slightly faster, and I said, look, can you teach me Latin, enough Latin, to get through this exam in three weeks?
Oh, he said, sure, of course, no problem.
He said, come round to me every evening, and I'll send a bill to your father.
And I said, well, that's all right.
And so I went round to him every evening for about half an hour,
First evening we got in, he said, well now, set for Horace's odes.
Here's the Latin, here's the English.
You learn the English off by heart as far as you can.
You know enough Latin words to know which ode you've got.
And with knowing just a little Latin, you should be able to pick your way through.
Oh, he said, by the way, don't bother with these three.
They won't ask those.
And I said, why not?
Oh, he said, they're obscene.
So I said, well, listen, look, I read the English text.
I said, I can't say anything obscene about them.
What's wrong with them?
Oh, he said, you see, that's a boy's name.
They'll never say anything about buggery to a public school boy.
He said, you can safely omit those.
I mean, by modern standards, very odd system of education, but it suited me.
to be left to my own devices, so to speak.
Well, I think I got interested in writing properly in this environment.
I mean, it was one of the things that was highly regarded and which a lot of trouble was taken about.
And later on, Lance Cunningham was very fussy about how I wrote things, and this man Jeffreys I talked about.
It was a thing which was not regarded casually.
It was regarded...
as perhaps the most important part of education, to learn to write grammatically correctly.
And I know what's gone wrong with American writing of students.
You quite properly start off with small children to teach them that they can express themselves.
You don't bother much how they do it.
You tell them to write about their pet cat or something of this kind, and you don't much worry whether they spell cat with K and how it's done.
But the trouble is this goes on all through school and all through college, that there's a very high value put on self-expression as against formal correctness of writing.
And I had an interesting example of this.
A young lady in my class here in San Diego wrote a midterm test which was literally unintelligible.
sort her out, and said, I can't grade this thing.
And she said, why not?
I said, because it doesn't make any sense.
And she said, what do you mean?
I said, well, just read it to me.
And we sat down, and she read it to me.
And after a little while, she said, I said, what do you mean?
It doesn't make sense, does it?
I said, no, it doesn't.
She said, no one's ever said this to me before.
It's interesting.
They all thought I wrote like I wrote, and that was that.
And I said, well,
Look, it isn't any good, is it?
I said, you go away and do two more questions that I'll give you.
Take your time, do what you like, get anyone's advice you like, ask your dog, anyone, and come back next week with it.
She came back and got an A.
She suddenly realized.
It had never, I think, entered her head that there was any more problem in writing than there is in speaking.
She thought it was a thing you did spontaneously, and the first thing that came into your head was the best way to do it.
And I think it is the realization that writing is an art, is a conscious effort, which I think your students are missing.
Such a high value is placed on spontaneity of expression, that the fact that writing is not, that apparent spontaneity in writing is obtained with great difficulty, but
People like, what's the man's name, the man who wrote Ulysses?
Joyce.
Joyce, yes.
I mean, it's apparently, he's the source of this kind of thing.
It's done with enormous subtlety, and it's obviously been rewritten dozens of times.
This realization just hasn't got through.
It's the school's fault.
They aren't insisting that people write intelligibly.
Well, anyway, you asked me about what I thought about writing in America and England.
I think it's just more trouble is taken in insisting on correct writing.
And you think, then, that you're typical of this product rather than...
I think so.
I mean, maybe I've had more practice than most people.
I mean, I've written an awful lot.
The book...
How did you come to invent the geophonic device you used in your work?
I had that appearing in the 30s in work with Strada.
Oh, this is this...
I know what you're talking about.
You're talking about geophones.
Yeah.
Well, when we were working on land and seismology, we had no money.
So we had to make our own geophones.
I don't think we invented anything.
It was pretty obvious how to do it.
They existed.
I mean, there was the wear seismographs being used by all companies and so on.
And we thought a bit about how they should be designed and how they were made.
And we made one, and then we had to make one to use at sea.
And the trick about this was it had to work either way up, because you couldn't determine which way it went down the sea floor.
We started the first year putting them right way up on the sea bottom, which is quite a trick.
And then we decided that's too much nuisance and made ones that go either way up.
I was very lucky.
I had an extraordinarily clever assistant.
He was a boy who'd left school at 15, had taken a course in machining.
He was a mechanic, a machinist.
And he was about the cleverest man I'd ever met.
And this was a nice thing, at least it was nice for me in the 20s and 30s,
were a whole lot of people who fell off the educational ladder, who were extremely intelligent.
And the result was that you could get very intelligent people as assistants.
Whereas now, of course, this man would have been chairman of General Motors or something, or a banker, or God knows what he was.
In fact, my mechanic.
And I always felt he was much cleverer than I was.
And he did very well during the war, which is another story we might come to.
But he had no ambition at all.
He insisted after the war on coming back and working as a mechanic.
Very curious.
When you go to East Africa, did you deliberately go there on a scientific expedition?
And if so, who sent you?
Well, I sent myself, essentially.
We developed these methods of measuring gravity with pendulums for considerable improvement on them.
If anyone wants to know how it was done, they can read the paper in the philosophical transactions.
And East Africa is a very odd place.
Some friends of mine had been there looking at the Rift Valleys from a geological point of view, and biologists and so on.
So I knew a little about East Africa.
It was accessible.
It was a British colony.
The road system was sufficiently good to travel about in it.
a certain number of height measurements, which were important.
There'd been leveling along the railway.
There'd been a triangulation.
It was just in a sufficiently developed state to do gravity measuring.
A little had been done already by a German in Tanzania, which was formerly a German East Africa, a man called .
And it has the rift valleys, which I was interested in.
And so I chose it for its scientific interest plus the practicability of the project.
And I went out with my wife, and we traveled around in a truck, slept in the truck, took all the equipment in the truck, and a couple of natives, who was a cook and his assistant.
And we spent several months there traveling around.
It was really a tremendous trip around with all this equipment.
Well, so that I mean, one of the things we had to do,
generally speaking, was to build our equipment, you see, because you couldn't.
We had no money to buy equipment.
Now, I always try, if you can buy equipment, you buy it.
And, of course, equipment's much more available now.
The whole scientific enterprise is so much bigger.
And all the things like cathedrals, scilographs, analog-digital converters, all these things are available on a big scale.
Well, look, we've only just, you know, we've been talking about it now, and we've only just got to the point where I talk about oceanography.
